fields.description:
The idea is to give feedback as soon as possible if the JDK that the developer uses is not version 1.5 or above. 
This is a good idea for the release process as the X-team deals with many different project and their base jdk is 1.4.

This is easily done using the [maven-enforcer-plugin|http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-enforcer-plugin].
fields.summary: Use the enforcer plugin to fail fast if a developer uses a jdk below 1.5

fields.description:
The group list on the viewGroups page maxes out at 100, if there are more than 100 groups not all are shown and since there is no search function on the groups page, there is no way to edit groups.

As a workaround, manually change the "startIndex" value in the URL to 100.
fields.summary: The ViewGroups page can only show a maximum of 100 groups, when integrated with LDAP

fields.description: Raised due to https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-428, we need to document the logging aspect of Bamboo better, especially how to manipulate the log4j.properties file.

fields.description:
Currently SVN changes are only picked up if SVN:Externals is defined in the projects root.

SVN changes are not picked up, if SVN:Externals are defined in the sub folders.
fields.summary: SVN:Externals changes are not picked up in sub-folders

fields.description:
Bamboo uses comma separated values to differentiate between multiple groups when setting notification rules for groups.

However, if a group is coming off LDAP having ", " characters in between, Bamboo thinks they are to separate distinct groups.
fields.summary: Can't set notification rules for group names with ", " letter in between.

fields.description: The upgrade guide doesn't mention anything about, how to re-enable crowd/LDAP integration. This must be part of the upgrade guide.
fields.summary: Review the upgrade guide.

fields.description: We're considering using TFS as our Java source control system (we are already using it for our .NET projects). Will Bamboo be supprting this at any stage?
fields.summary: Support for Team Foundation Server

fields.description: Now that the build logs have been seperated from th build results xml files it is possible to provide the capability similar to artifacts to give the option as to whether or not the logs should be included in the export.
fields.summary: Option to not export build logs

fields.description:
Ajay to confirm whether this page needs to be updated: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/5.08+Granting+Global+Permissions+to+Users+or+Groups

... as per case-sensitive notes on this page: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/5.07+Granting+Plan+Permissions+to+Users+or+Groups
fields.summary: add note about LDAP user/group names being case-sensitive

fields.description:
Situation:

I setup bamboo with the global permission 'Access' for 'Anonymous users' disabled. 

However, if you create a new plan and allow access for 'Anonymous users' in specific plan, users that are not logged in can still access the project.

IMHO the plan specific permissions should not override the global permissions. We do want our developers to create new plans, but we don't want them to bother with the permissions.
fields.summary: Users should not be able to view plans if Global Anonymous access is disabled.

fields.description: Having exposed our developers to the Bamboo "scoring" report the debate has been intense. There are a variety of views on what could be the perfect scoring algorithm and many are specific to our environment and breakdown of builds and teams. So I've raised this Jira to request a way of customising the scoring system on a per-installation basis. Perhaps via the Administration UI rather than the normal plugin mechanism for ease of feedback.
fields.summary: Pluggable scoring mechanism

fields.description: Failed builds should not be counted in Clover coverage metrics. Please see attached coverage graph.
fields.summary: Bamboo Clover plugin should not count failed builds in coverage metrics

fields.description:
When adding permissions to LDAP users with capital cases - I was able to add permissions for LDAP user with wrong case, this means when users login the permissions are not assigned.

From BSP-413 - 
{quote}
A test case for this would be:
1) Have a user from LDAP with a mixed case username that Bamboo sees and lists with that case in the user browser (from your example, ASPNET)
2) In a plan, grant that user some special permissions but give it to a differently-cased version of the username (aspnet)
3) Verify that the plan permissions list the user with the differently-cased version you gave it
4) Log out and log in as the LDAP user
5) Verify that you do NOT have the permission you should for that plan
6) Log out and login as admin user, update the plan permissions to match the username as displayed by Bamboo exactly (ASPNET)
7) Log back in as the LDAP user, you should have the permission now
{quote}
fields.summary: Adding permissions for a user should check that the username exactly matches

fields.description:
The project names can overflow quite hideously on the Bamboo dashboard. See attached screenshot.

Sam wrote a blog a while ago about how to avoid this in a way that works in IE6/7, Safari and Firefox:

http://blogs.atlassian.com/developer/2007/08/post.html
fields.summary: Fix overflow of project names on dashboard

fields.description: When searching for users on viewUsers page, if I enter an wild pattern such as Chris*johns (firstname*lastname) Bamboo will throw an freemarker exception.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to perform wild card matches, when searching viewUsers page if the text is wrapped around a '*' wildcard character
REST API Login.action does not work if anonymous user access to plans is disabled.

fields.description: We currently save build logs from our tests as build artifacts.  These logs get to about 30MB, which takes quite some time to download.  It would be great if Bamboo had an option to automatically compress build artifacts.
fields.summary: Automatically compress build artifacts

fields.description:
There are a handful of things that either need to be installed in the bamboo installation directory or that live in the installation directory and need to be tweaked.  All of these make upgrading from one version to the next not as trivial as it could be.  Here are some examples:

* Plugins are copied into <install.dir>/webapp/WEB-INF/lib
* JDBC driver is copied into <install.dir>/webapp/WEB-INF/lib
* Authentication configuration is tweaked and lives in <install.dir>/webapp/WEB-INF/classes/atlassian-user.xml
* The home directory is set in <install.dir>/webapp/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-init.properties (or BAMBOO_HOME env var)
* Startup JVM args (max memory) in bamboo.sh (set as an ENV variable: BAMBOO_OPTS?)

I'd like to be able to upgrade Bamboo without having to muck with any of these files.  I think this could be accomplished fairly easily by externalizing all of these under the BAMBOO_HOME directory.  Java 1.6 supports wildcards on the classpath (BAMBOO_HOME/plugins/\*.jar and BAMBOO_HOME/lib/\*.jar), and I bet there's a less-elegant way to get the same functionality on older JVMs.

In the end, it would be great if a point-release upgrade looked like this:

# Unzip new version into unique directory (e.g. bamboo-1.2.4)
# Stop old bamboo (e.g. bamboo-1.2.0/bamboo.sh stop)
# Start the new bamboo (e.g. bamboo-1.2.4/bamboo.sh start)
fields.summary: Externalize all configuration, plugins, and properties fromt the bamboo installation

fields.description: The files tab should check what type the latest build's agent was and if it was a local agent, then show the files tab. This isn't perfect but it's a pretty reasonable compromise for now
fields.summary: Fix up files tab

fields.description:
I disabled anonymous access to Bamboo today and enabled LDAP authentication for users. I have LDAP authentication turned on, but I do not have "external user management" enabled so that I can have bamboo-only accounts and groups.

This seems to have partially broken the JIRA Bamboo Plug-in. I have updated the account information in JIRA with a non-ldap account that is able to login to Bamboo outside of the system fine.

The "Bamboo Status" portlet works correctly, it is able to retrieve the current status of all plans and display the information accordingly.

The "Bamboo Plan Summary" portlet is now broken. In the configuration options it shows "No plans were found - authentication failed. Remote API may be disabled on Bamboo".

This is obviously incorrect since Remote API is enabled, the account itself is fine and the other portlet is able to get the plan information without a problem.

Any ideas on how to resolve this?
fields.summary: Bamboo plug-in broken by authentication

fields.description:
For long-running builds & occasionally-failing tests, it's often useful to run a single test / suite on Bamboo without wanting the whole plan to run again.  Right now, to do this you have to create a new plan to run the test(s) within Bamboo.

Bamboo could support this with some kind of variable-substitution scheme built into it, running a different target when "Run This Test" is clicked, it calls another commandline with the test suite substituted.

For example, our command build is:
 clean with.clover compile test-all -Dtests.writetofileonly=true -Dhidetestname=true clover2html tests-failguard 

For a 'Run This Test', the command would be something like:
 clean with.clover compile test-one-lw -Dclass={$MyTestSuite} -Dtests.writetofileonly=true -Dhidetestname=true clover2html tests-failguard 

The difference between the two is that 'test-all' becomes 'test-one-lw', and the suite is added as a parameter.  (This is unique to our ant script, and would likely be different among every environment out there, which is why I suggest a completely different commandline that each plan would have for 'Run This Test'.)
fields.summary: Add "Run This Test Again", if configured right

fields.description:
Applying following configuration of a Project
* Pooling on SVN Repository
* Build Goals : clean package deploy release:prepare --batch-mode release:perform

In SVN Repository :
*  the *build-number.txt* is added in svnignore
* The current Project Version is set to 1.0-SNAPSHOT

At the first execution, the Build perform all goals correctly :
* *clean* and *package* provide a new SNAPSHOT binary
* *deploy* deploys the *1.0.0-SNAPSHOT* on Maven Repository
* *release:prepare --batch-mode* defines the release informations in *release.properties* on build Dir.
* *release:perform* releases the project by :
** Updating version from *1.0.0-SNAPSHOT* to *1.0.0*
** Releasing the *1.0.0* to *TagBase* URL
** Updating version from *1.0.0* t o*1.0.1-SNAPSHOT* in the trunk
** Extract of release 1.0 in _*Build.Dir.*\target\checkout_
** *deploy* and  *site-deploy* execution, providing a new released binary

After execution, a new release is tagged on SVN and the SVN Trunk is ready for the next SNAPSHOT release.
The Maven repostory is updated with SNAPSHOT and RELEASE repository.

But sadely, in the next pooling phase, Bamboo reexecutes the Build, because, there are two new changes :
* [maven-release-plugin] prepare release maven-checkstyle-plugin-config-1.0.0
    ** /sfri/trunk/maven-checkstyle-plugin-config/pom.xml (version 7661)
* [maven-release-plugin] prepare for next development iteration
   ** /sfri/trunk/maven-checkstyle-plugin-config/pom.xml (version 7663)

Then, each Build make some changes, then after each SVN pool, the Build is restarted.

What is the best way to manage release from Bamboo whitout having more than [one plan per SVN URLs|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-1875] ?

The only short term solution, should be to launch a *scm:update* goal after the release. 
* Build Goals Tested : clean package deploy release:prepare --batch-mode release:perform scm:update
* Build Goals not yet tested : clean package deploy release:prepare --batch-mode scm:update release:perform 

What may be the best practice ?

Rgds
fields.summary: Usage of Maven2 Goals release:prepare and release:perform

fields.description:
In the next release, I have made changes to the external management section of Bamboo - so that the text is clear on instructing customers that:

* External User Management should only be enabled when using with LDAP.
* External User Management should *IS NOT* meant for Crowd!

The text on the page now reads - "Enable this option if you are delegating your user management to LDAP. If you are using CROWD leave this box unchecked."
As opposed to - "Enable this option if you are delegating your user management to another user management system (e.g. Crowd)."
which gives the impression that the external user management should be enabled for crowd - doing so leaves the email and full name fields null as per BAM-1681 and is not recommended!

For this, the http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/5.13+Working+with+External+User+Repositories page need to be scrapped!
fields.summary: Update the docs on external user management in Bamboo.

fields.description:
I made a mistake setting the dependencies for the IE Selenium Build. I accidentally set the JIRA Func Tests Build to be its child build, instead of its parent build. When I went back in to update it I selected the JIRA Func Tests Build as a parent build and deselected it as a child build. When I saved the changes Bamboo complained that I had created a circular dependency and didn't deselct the JIRA Func Tests Build as a child build. 

In order to make it work I had to deselect the JIRA Func Tests Build as a child build. Save changes. Select the JIRA Func Tests Build as a parent and save changes.

Not a serious issue but kind of annoying
fields.summary: Selecting a build as a parent and deselecting it as a child doesn't work

fields.description:
Tests which have been running fine for months using cron scheduling, ran exactly one hour late. Is there a possible Daylight savings issue here? The clock on the OS was correct at the time this occurred.

Build Strategy: Cron Based Scheduling
Cron Expression: 0 0 8 ? * FRI


FYI:
I somehow created this issue on support.atlassian.com: BSP-385. this is probably a more appropriate place for it.
fields.summary: Cron Schedule was off by one hour

fields.description:
This issue has been discussed before as part of an bigger issue (BAM-1681). To prevent any confusion about what the issue is I created an new issue.

The problem is as follows:

- Use external usermanagement is turned on in bamboo
- Add an Jabber account to your bamboo profile
- When saving the email adres is removed from the Crowd principal. This is very undesired behavior!

In issue BAM-1681 Justin Koke stated the documentation would reflect that external user management should be turned off. However the documentation still is explicit about turning it *ON*:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/3.2.2+Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Bamboo

Furthermore, I can't understand that Bamboo still does not support external user management with Crowd. I'm not trying any 3th party tools here. I'm trying to integrate with an tool from Atlassian itself! Leaving external user management in bamboo OFF is very disappointing to us. Please provide a real solution for integration with Crowd asap.
fields.summary: External User Management still does not work when integration with Crowd

fields.description: Bamboo doesn't handle disabled Notification plugins well, causing NullPointer exceptions when viewing the build configuration.
fields.summary: Configured notification plugins may cause an error if plugin is removed

fields.description:
I  have noticed this in several support issues where after restart the bamboo.cfg.xml file is null!

{code}
2007-10-31 08:24:29,021 FATAL [main] [BootstrapLoaderListener] An error was enco
untered while bootstrapping Bamboo (see below):
Unable to bootstrap Bamboo: Failed to parse config file: Error on line -1 of document  : Premature end of file. Nested exception: Premature end of file.java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to bootstrap Bamboo: Failed to parse config file: Error on line -1 of document  : Premature end of file. Nested exception: Premature end of file.
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.setup.BootstrapLoaderListener.contextInitialized(BootstrapLoaderListener.java:65)
        at org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationContext.doStart(WebApplicationContext.java:497)
        at org.mortbay.jetty.plus.PlusWebAppContext.doStart(PlusWebAppContext.java:149)
        at org.mortbay.util.Container.start(Container.java:72)
        at org.mortbay.http.HttpServer.doStart(HttpServer.java:753)
        at org.mortbay.jetty.plus.Server.doStart(Server.java:153)
        at org.mortbay.util.Container.start(Container.java:72)
{code}

A quick fix would be to point to a new Bamboo-home and replace the null bamboo.cfg.xml with your new bamboo.cfg.xml file.
fields.summary: Bamboo.cfg.xml file is null after restart.

fields.description:
In Bamboo, a watcher for a plan is a user who has the plan (in question) in his favorites list.

When a new user is, creating a plan and setting up build notifications - this concept is alien, as we use 2 different terms (watchers and favourite plans) in different parts.

We should document the concept of watchers better, or should we even use the term watchers so loosely?

From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-382
fields.summary: The concept of watchers in Bamboo notifications page is ambigious

fields.description:
Freemarker (?) appears to be processing the URL included in the changelog text munging it such that the link doesn't work. e.g. This plaintext in the changelog {code} Add httpd as a derived source revision: 244 changeset: 158667ffb7a1 URL: http://scc.eng.rpath.com/​bob/​rev/​158667ffb7a1 {code} becomes this on the web page {code}

Add httpd as a derived source
revision: 244 changeset: 158667ffb7a1
URL: http://scc.eng.rpath.com/​bob/​rev/​158667ffb7a1

{code}
fields.summary: Change log entries that contain URLs appear fine on screen but the actual HREF is mangled

fields.description:
In a number of places, the only distinguishing factor between a passed/failed builds is the color.  Somewhere between 7%-10% of males are red/green color blind (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_blindness).  We have a developer that's been using the product for 6 months and just realized that there is a difference between failed/passed builds.

Specifically, the "My Bamboo tab" sections: Favorite plans, My Latest Changes are what developers refer to most.

Adding an icon or making the text bold would help.
fields.summary: Impossible to distinguish between successful/failed builds if red/green color blind

fields.description: see https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-370#action_163827
fields.summary: mention that LDAP accounts take priority over local accounts with the same name

fields.description:
Presently, the PublishArtifactFile class creates temporary files for each artifact when it is deserialised.  These are then copied to the appopriate directory, and are never deleted.

To ensure that temporary files do not gather, and to improve performance, these files should be moved, rather than copied.
fields.summary: Server should move, rather than copy, artifacts from remote builds

fields.description: It is currently hard-coded to exist in /tmp/kaha
fields.summary: ActiveMQ peristent store should be located within bamboo home

fields.description:
The segmented message solution implemented for transferring artifacts from remote agents to the server has a performance bottleneck on the server side that should be investigated.

Performance I was seeing in a test environment was in the order of 100 KB/s.
fields.summary: Improve server-side performance of artifact transfer

fields.description: See screenshot.  Says 'optional'  but is required.
fields.summary: Code coverage setup says optional, but is required

fields.description:
From following these instructions: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/7.4+Moving+your+Bamboo+Data+to+a+different+Database.

It is clear in these docs that you need to use a different install and home directories, which made it sound like it was ok to use the same build and working directories, but it appears that both of these directories have been cleared.  This was not expected.  Also, why did all the working copies (SVN) have to be deleted if they were going to match the builds in the backup I was starting from?
fields.summary: Please clarify that starting with an import is going to delete your working-directory

fields.description: I cannot afford to include all of my artifacts in my nightly backup, but it would be great to be able to include artifacts from *some* builds - perhaps important ones like milestone builds or releases.  If I could provide a list of labels whose build's artifact's could be included in the backup - that would be great.
fields.summary: Option to only backup artifacts with specific labels

fields.description:
For an identified project, we need to :
# Validate the Continuus Integration during the intra-day
# Be able to deploy nightly a SNAPSHOT Artifact on Maven Repository (deploy goal)
# Be able to deploy nightly an EAR Project to our Qualification J2EE Application Server (inhouse deployEAR goal)
# Be able to execute Selenium Test from Maven Goal on successed deployed EAR
# Be able to Release a Version (release:prepare and release:perform goals)
# Be able to deploy a RELEASE Artifact on Maven Repository (deploy goal)

With current version Bamboo (1.2.3, and perhaps 1.2.4), to apply such mechanism, if I have well understand, a Plan will have to be duplicated (cloned) for each set of Goals.
|| Plans || Set of Maven Goals | 
|| 1 | clean package | 
|| 2 | clean deploy | 
|| 3 | clean package release:clean deployEAR selenium:start-server --batch-mode release:prepare release:perform deploy | 

It means that for each project, the Working Directory will be also duplicated, then increase :
* the Time of Build : each Plan will have to build the same artifact with the same project (same SCM reference)
* the Disk Space required. 

It would be very usefull to be able to define a Set of Goals, with dedicated scheduler, with _*Builder Configuration*_ panel is as follow :
*Builder:*  Maven 2.0.7
*Goal's Sets:* 
||  N°  ||   Goals || Scheduled || Conditions || Description | 
|  1 |   clean package |  each 1800s | None | Intra-Day integration | 
|  2 |   deploy |  at 20:00 | Set 1 Ok | Nightly Deploy (SNAPSHOT) |
|  3 |   release:clean deployEAR selenium:start-server --batch-mode release:prepare release:perform deploy | at 20:00 | Set 1 Ok | Nightly Qualification |
*Build JDK:*  1.5.0_12  

A almost similar feature does exist with Continuum, it would be VERY USEFULL to retrieve it with Bamboo.
fields.summary: Ability to configure more than one set of Maven goals for a Plan

fields.description:
Update the docs on http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/3.2.2+Triggering+a+Build+on+Code+Check-in to make it clear as to what the scripts actually accomplish, it might also be useful to give working examples of how to use the script. 

Created due to BAM-1730
fields.summary: The doco for the trigger scripts in Bamboo is not clear.

fields.description: If you create a new build plan and disable it during the initial checkout the UI is incorrectly colored.
fields.summary: Bamboo UI is incorrect if plan has been disabled while it is doing its initial checkout

fields.description:
It would be excellent if Bamboo had the ability for someone to comment directly on a particular test (suite or method) on the build results page.  This would let teams of >2 people easily communicate information about specific tests, such as who's working on it or fixed it.  This is immediately useful for larger projects where the suite doesn't run after every commit (and instead runs on a schedule).

The rationale behind the request is that we have a build that take 2.5 hours to complete, including all kinds of lengthy integration tests.  It's not feasible to run the build after every commit, so we run it once a night.  We're in the process of fixing up a large amount of failures (~100), and multiple people are tackling the code at once.  Bamboo already provides a central location for knowing what tests to fix.  We currently use IM to send status of "I'm working on XXX", but it's difficult to remember what's been fixed throughout the day, and what new things there are to work on.

If the comments could be added directly into Bamboo's test results display, so that we can see "XXX failed.  Timmy says: working on it.  Timmy says: Fixed," and know not to do it.

(Yes, there's all sorts of other ways this could be done.. such as using the 'Comments' page, or JIRA, or emails, etc...  but including it in the page that we already use to show us what tests need fixing is the ideal solution.)

Thanks!
fields.summary: Comments per test / suite

fields.description:
Bamboo seems to detect newly failing tests and fixed tests by the test's name.  This works really well, but falls short when some tests don't run in a build.  Reasons for a test not running include: the test timed out causing a failure in a test named 'Unknown' and all passing tests aren't recorded, a static method prior to running any test fails [more applicable in JUnit4] causing no tests to run.

What happens now is that Bamboo sends emails and generates pages that list all the newly failing tests, all the old fail tests, and all the once-failed-now-succesful tests.  This causes it to look like nothing changed on the tests that were fixed because the test-methods themselves never ran.

I propose one of two changes:
 Option 1) Include newly-ran tests in the newly-succesful list, except instead of saying "Last Failed In", say "First Run".
 Option 2) Include a new-tests section and list every newly-run test, and whether it failed or succeeded.  (And include a XXX new tests # in emails.)

Option 1 fits better into the existing page layout, but Option 2 gives a lot more information.  Either one will work for us.
fields.summary: Add # of and names of new succesful tests

fields.description:
From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-359 :

Although Bamboo 1.2 and later does collect Clover results for failed builds, it doesn't include their statistics in the Clover graphs. We believe this is what most of our customers would want, because coverage data for failed builds can't be compared against coverage data for successful builds. If we were to include statistics for failed builds, the graph would leap about, and would no longer depict the trend of successful build coverage over time, which is what we believe most of our customers are interested in monitoring.

The problem is [not restricted to Clover graphs|BAM-2160].

For periods of time when you have no successful builds, the graphs show zero values. This too prevents Bamboo users from monitoring the trend over time.

The problem isn't related to failed builds, as such, it's related to time periods with no successful builds; if you don't run any builds for a period of time, you will see the same problem.

We're thinking that the best solution may be to modify the graphs so that there is no data point for time periods with no successful builds. There would simply be a straight line segment from the previous time period with a successful build to the next period with a successful build. This would prevent days without successful builds from interfering with the display of the trend over time.
fields.summary: Graphs should not show data points for time periods with no successful builds

fields.description: Many times a single repository isn't sufficient as the source of changes for triggering builds. In our particular case, we have plans that need to observe (and consume) multiple Mercurial source repositories and also consider additional binary repositories in conjunction. If any of these change, we want to rebuild with the aggregate of the changelogs of all repositories noted as the build reason.
fields.summary: Support multiple repositories per plan
Publish source for JIRA Bamboo plugin

fields.description:
We have two build queues, the Default and a new one. In order to ensure that long-running builds do not block all builds we assign to the other queue, and customise the default queue so that it cannot run in that queue.

However, with this configuration, when we create a new plan it is NOT automatically assigned to a build queue. And so when the first build is kicked off we get an error because the plan is not assigned to a queue. I've assgined priority minor because there is a manual workaround but raised a bug as it's not very user-friendly.

Aside: a better abstraction of assigning plans to queues would be appreciated, i.e. there is no way to say "this plan runs ONLY in this queue", instead one has to assign all the other projects individually to include/exclude on a queue by queue basis, when at the beginning you just want to make sure that one build runs in one queue and one queue only.
fields.summary: Project not automatically assigned to default queue

fields.description:
The validation of at least the "From Address" and possibly other addresses is incorrect. It refuses perfectly legitimate RFC 2822 compliant addresses that can contain apostrophes - such as:
john.o'reilly@network.com

I believe this has been fixed in other Atlassian products but not in Bamboo.
fields.summary: Email From Address validation is wrong in Configure Mail Server

fields.description:
The Crowd libraries in Bamboo need updating to get around an error found with XFire http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/XFIRE-888

This should mean the following for Bamboo's parent pom.

{code:xml}
<dependency>
  <groupId>woodstox</groupId>
  <artifactId>wstx-asl</artifactId>
  <version>3.2.0</version>
</dependency>
<dependency>
   <groupId>org.codehaus.xfire</groupId>
   <artifactId>xfire-all</artifactId>
  <version>1.2.6</version>
</dependency>
{code}
fields.summary: Move the XFire dependency for Crowd from 1.2.1 to 1.2.6

fields.description: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+Bamboo+over+Https
fields.summary: review HTTPS page

fields.description:
When a build is executed and in certain cases, where SVN update fails - Bamboo doesn't stop trying to update the logs.

Scenario 2 - the connection to SVN is lost and when a build is executed Bamboo is in a flux state trying to checkout and there is no way to stop the build.

We had a limit on how many times Bamboo tries to update.
fields.summary: Set a time limit on number of times Bamboo tries to checkout.

fields.description:
For UI tests, it's convenient to be able to run a VNC server during a build run, a la:
http://hudson.gotdns.com/wiki/display/HUDSON/Xvnc+Plugin
fields.summary: Run VNC During Build

fields.description: Our company build monitoring system monitors several different build servers and does not need to know of all builds. Basically, we would like to trigger notifications for all failed builds and the first successful. This is possible to get from bamboo e-mail notifications and would be very useful to have from bamboo rss feeds as well.
fields.summary: rss feed for "Failed Builds And First Successful"

fields.description:
We have a scheduled backup set to run every 3 days, and it pretty much always fails with:

2007-10-21 01:00:00,021 ERROR [QuartzScheduler_Worker-9] [ScheduledBackupJob] com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.ImportExportException: Bamboo is busy. Please wait until all builds in queue have f
inished or manually stop the builds.
com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.ImportExportException: Bamboo is busy. Please wait until all builds in queue have finished or manually stop the builds.
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.migration.ImportExportManagerImpl.bambooExport(ImportExportManagerImpl.java:49)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.configuration.ScheduledBackupJob.execute(ScheduledBackupJob.java:68)
        at org.quartz.core.JobRunShell.run(JobRunShell.java:203)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.quartz.SystemAuthorizedThreadPool$1.run(SystemAuthorizedThreadPool.java:36)
        at org.quartz.simpl.SimpleThreadPool$WorkerThread.run(SimpleThreadPool.java:520)


This is probably because we have a build set to run early in the morning that takes a few hours.  The scheduled backup should wait until the build is finished and then do a backup instead of failing immediately and never performing the backup.
fields.summary: Scheduled Backup Fails if build is in queue

fields.description:
It would be extremely useful to have multiple builders for a particular build, run in sequence.

The particular use case is MSBuild+NUnit. We'd love to have a single MSBuild configuration for the compilation, and then separately kick off NUnit either directly (as a builder) or via NAnt.
fields.summary: Multiple builders for a particular build configuration

fields.description: It would be useful if, just like there's a Clover and JUnit tab on a particular build, there was an FXCop tab showing FXCop status as well.
fields.summary: FXCop integration
Cron Scheduled builds not building

fields.description: Bamboo should support ncover - .Net coverage tool.
fields.summary: Support for NCover coverage report

fields.description:
Would be nice to allow users to find the sum total of jira issues fixed in a range of builds i.e. BUILD-12 to BUILD-18 contains ?? jira issues.


This would help our QA teams know what they have in the build because they don't take every build and need to know whats fixed since the last QA build.
fields.summary: Jira issues fixed in a range of builds

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo looks for the BUILD SUCCESSFUL in the last X lines of output and return code status to determine the outcome of the build.

In future, users should be given an option of defining their own criteria to judge build outcome. Such as,
# Should Bamboo look for the BUILD SUCCESSFUL message?
# If so, how many number of lines should Bamboo look for - to check if the BUILD SUCCESSFUL message exists?
# Return codes for build status.
fields.summary: Allow users to define the criteria for their Maven/Ant build outcomes.

fields.description: .svn folders included in Bamboo releases in  <Bamboo-root>/scripts/perforce-triggers/.svn directory.
fields.summary: Bamboo releases include .svn folder

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo backup does not export ServerID - this mean when migrating databases or upgrading Bamboo by import/export process the serverID is lost!

Bamboo export should include ServerID.
fields.summary: Bamboo does not export ServerID

fields.description: We have our mail server setup and working fine in Bamboo, but when someone changes a password it gives them a big warning that the SMTP Server isn't setup correctly and to contact an administrator.  Is there something else we have to do?  (We don't have either a user/pw set or JNDI settings -- mail it sent from localhost using sendmail.)
fields.summary: Mail Server is Setup, but Gives Warning It Isn't

fields.description:
Not clear whether this is a bug or an enhancement as doc is not explicit on the subject.

The triggering of builds based on dependencies is rather primitive.

Let's take an example: plan A depends on B & C. Both B & C depend on D.

If D changes we would like that B and C, then A, are compiled, ONCE. What actually happens is that B & C are both compiled (fine) but then A is compiled twice.

Evidently this is not efficient, and in a large tree of dependencies as we have, means that project compilation takes much longer than it should.
fields.summary: Implement intelligent dependency checking

fields.description: I have a build plan that contains no unit tests and to my knowledge builds properly but Bamboo still says failed. How does Bamboo determine a successful build because I also noticed that from the logs this build doesn't display the signature Maven BUILD SUCCESSFUL message. Could this be the problem?
fields.summary: Build failed even when files have been generated and no tests
Builders should be validated before a build starts

fields.description:
At the moment agent will attempt to restart if communication with the server fails (this could be the server going down). This doesn't work well in certain cases due to 

* SVNKit not shutting down the timer threads correctly (known case)
* Anything not shutting down in time

We should try to get the agent to:
* Shutdown properly - so that it can restart.
* Log that it's shutting down, and minimise the exceptions that are logged
fields.summary: Agent bootstrapper restart if server goes down / communication error occurs

fields.description: I'm not sure that panda has _ever_ remembered my login.
fields.summary: Fix "remember my login" on panda.

fields.description: I haven't been receiving IM notifications on Panda, and I can't see anything wrong with my config.
fields.summary: Fix IM notifications on panda

fields.description:
Addition of an Administration Error Console as a self diagnostic tool.

Ideally, this page would serve the following purpose - 
# Warn users of problems with their Bamboo instances -  low disk space, low memory etc.
# Scan Bamboo logs for exceptions.
# Look out for common Bamboo exceptions, warn  users and suggest solutions to issue, a typical example of this would be read lock error with Lucene locks.

A further extension of this feature would be to -
# Mail/IM Bamboo-admins or whoever administers Bamboo, with warning messages in case of Bamboo needing immediate attention!
# Link the admin console to the Atlassian Bamboo knowledge Base - so that users can search.
fields.summary: Bamboo should have an Administration Erorr Console - as a self diagnostic tool.

fields.description:
I should be able to give a p4web port and have much better integration with p4web, so that I have links that I can click on emails and in the Bamboo GUI that would allow me to go directly to p4web.

For example, it would be useful to be able to see the file that changed, and click on a link to show the delta in p4web between that version and the previous version.
fields.summary: Better integration with p4web

fields.description: It would be extremely useful if we could get the emails coming out of Bamboo in a nicer HTML format, just like JIRA.
fields.summary: HTML Emails

fields.description:
Bamboo doe not aggregate all the clover report files it encounters instead only reporting the last one it encounters - this is a problem for a multi-module Maven 2 system.

From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=20624&tstart=0
fields.summary: Bamboo should aggregate multiple Clover XML outputs

fields.description: Although Throwable implements Serializable, in practice there are Throwables that are not serialisable.  For this reason, we shouldn't attempt to serialise Throwables to send them over JMS.
fields.summary: Rework ErrorUpdateHandler interface to accommodate non-serialisable Throwables.
Plugin points pre/post build on server and agents

fields.description: Originally reported in [BSP-345|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-345], Bamboo can't perform fresh checkout since the fileUtils unable to delete symlinks if they are pointed to the same directory and the file referencing the symlink is deleted before the symlink!
fields.summary: "Deleting all build files" does not  delete symlinks

fields.description: We are encountering regular problems caused by serialisation of unnecessary objects.  We need visibility of what is actually being included in the serialised object graph being passed in ObjectMessages.
fields.summary: Logging of serialized object graph

fields.description:
# Go to the "Current Activity" tab on the bamboo main page.
# Go down to the "Error Log" section at the bottom
# Click "View the Error" for one of the errors
# More details about the error comes up in a smaller browser window
# Click "Clear Error from log"
# *The log message is cleared and the small browser window navigates to the "Dashboard" tab of the bamboo main page, instead of being closed.*

To me it would make more sense to close the window.
fields.summary: The "View error details" pop-up doesn't close when the "clear error log" link is clicked
